entry.title: A Post Quantum Migration Proposal
entry.summary:
The discussion revolves around a proposal to enhance the security of Bitcoin transactions in the face of potential quantum computing threats. The proposal outlined suggests temporarily locking vulnerable coins during a specific phase, referred to as phase B, until a future block height X, which could be set 5-10 years in the future. This measure aims to buy time for the development and tightening of the zk-STARK proof system intended for phase C. The flexibility of this approach allows for the option of integrating phases B and C if quantum computing advances slower than anticipated or if phase C development progresses faster.
The conversation further explores the implications of temporary versus permanent restrictions on transactions involving vulnerable addresses. A shift towards temporary restrictions is advocated to avoid permanent loss of funds due to pre-signed transactions, such as those in Lightning Network force-closes, being invalidated by a permanent block. This approach is seen as more ethical, offering a chance for legitimate owners to recover their funds in the future without necessitating a hard fork of the Bitcoin protocol.
There's also a debate over the treatment of BIP360 P2QRH addresses under the proposed phases. These addresses, which can contain EC signature spending conditions, might inadvertently lock funds until phase C if phase B restricts EC spending from P2QRH UTXOs. To mitigate this, a suggestion is made to enforce rules that fail any EC checksig opcode unless a post-quantum (PQ) checksig opcode was executed earlier in the script. This would effectively prevent premature exposure of public keys to quantum attacks, aligning the security of P2QRH addresses with traditional pre-quantum UTXOs by requiring both EC and PQ signatures for transactions.
The discourse encapsulates the technical and ethical considerations of adapting Bitcoinâ€™s protocol to resist quantum computing threats. It emphasizes the need for careful planning and the implementation of flexible solutions that can protect users' assets while accommodating future technological developments.
